questions.prompt: 1. In BG 13.1, what does Krishna call the body and the field of activities within it?
choices: Kshetra (field) and Kshetrajna (the knower of the field)
questions.feedback: Krishna uses the metaphor of a field (body) and the knower (soul) within it.

questions.prompt: 2. In BG 13.2, who is the knower of the field?
choices: Krishna in all bodies; Me specifically
questions.feedback: Krishna identifies Himself as the Supreme Knower in all fields (bodies).

questions.prompt: 3. In BG 13.3, what is the distinction between kshetra and kshetrajna?
choices: Understanding this distinction is the basis of real knowledge
questions.feedback: The distinction between the field (matter) and its knower (spirit) is essential knowledge.

questions.prompt: 4. In BG 13.5-12, what are the components of the field (kshetra)?
choices: Mahabhutani (five gross elements), ego, intelligence, and the unmanifested eternal nature
questions.feedback: The field comprises the five elements, mind, intelligence, ego, and the unmanifested prakriti.

questions.prompt: 5. In BG 13.13, what does Krishna say about the nature of knowledge regarding the field?
choices: It is eternal knowledge pervading the field in all aspects of life
questions.feedback: True knowledge is understanding the eternal nature that pervades all fields.

questions.prompt: 6. In BG 13.14, how is the Supreme realized?
choices: With untiring effort, everywhere; without and within of all moving and unmoving things
questions.feedback: The Supreme is realized through perceiving His presence everywhere in creation.

questions.prompt: 7. In BG 13.15, what are the characteristics of the Supreme one perceives?
choices: Undivided, separated from bodies, neither born nor dying, inexplicable
questions.feedback: The Supreme is beyond the material, unchanging, eternal, and the source of all.

questions.prompt: 8. In BG 13.17, where does the Supreme Brahman reside according to this verse?
choices: Within and without all creatures; it is the sustaining power of all existence
questions.feedback: The Supreme Brahman is both transcendental and present everywhere sustaining all creation.

questions.prompt: 9. In BG 13.19, how does Krishna describe knowledge itself?
choices: That knowing which one attains immortality; it is eternal knowledge of the Supreme
questions.feedback: True knowledge leads to immortality and eternal communion with the Supreme.

questions.prompt: 10. In BG 13.22-23, what do the three modes of nature control?
choices: They are responsible for the different types of bodies and experiences
questions.feedback: The three modes of nature create all variety in the material world, determining bodies and natures.

questions.prompt: 11. In BG 13.24, how does the jiva-atma (individual soul) become bound?
choices: By association with the modes of nature; due to ignorance, one thinks of oneself as the doer
questions.feedback: The soul becomes bound by identifying with the material modes and thinking itself as the actor.

questions.prompt: 12. In BG 13.25-26, what is the way to realize the Supreme?
choices: By meditating on the Self within; understanding the Supersoul within and transcendence
questions.feedback: Realization comes through meditation and understanding the Supersoul's presence.

questions.prompt: 13. In BG 13.27, what is the Supersoul's position?
choices: Situated in every heart; He is the source of light and consciousness
questions.feedback: The Supersoul resides in everyone's heart as the source of all consciousness and knowledge.

questions.prompt: 14. In BG 13.28-29, who realizes the Supreme and what is the result?
choices: One who sees the Supersoul and all beings equally within attains the eternal abode
questions.feedback: Those who see Krishna equally in all beings attain the eternal spiritual world.

questions.prompt: 15. In BG 13.30, what is the ultimate realization?
choices: Understanding Brahman and Paramatman; seeing the same Self in all beings
questions.feedback: The ultimate is realizing one's oneness with the Supreme while recognizing His presence in all.

questions.prompt: 16. In BG 13.2 (from purport), why is understanding the kshetrajna important?
choices: It is the basis for freedom from material bondage
questions.feedback: Understanding the spiritual knower leads to liberation from material existence.

questions.prompt: 17. In BG 13.3 (from purport), what is the consequence of not understanding this distinction?
choices: One remains in ignorance and material bondage
questions.feedback: Lack of this understanding keeps one trapped in the cycle of birth and death.

questions.prompt: 18. In BG 13.14-15 (from purport), how is the Supreme perceived by the realized?
choices: Through transcendental vision; everywhere and in everything
questions.feedback: The realized soul perceives the Supreme's presence pervading all creation through spiritual vision.

questions.prompt: 19. In BG 13.22-23 (from purport), why do different beings have different natures?
choices: Due to their association with different modes of nature
questions.feedback: The three modes determine individual natures and the types of bodies acquired.

questions.prompt: 20. In BG 13.27 (from purport), what is the significance of the Supersoul's presence?
choices: It indicates that all beings are monitored and controlled by the Supreme
questions.feedback: The Supersoul's presence signifies the Supreme's control and care for all creation.

questions.prompt: 21. In BG 13.24 (from purport), how does the soul become liberated?
choices: By understanding its distinction from matter and the Lord
questions.feedback: Liberation comes through realizing one's spiritual nature and the Lord's supremacy.

questions.prompt: 22. In BG 13.28-29 (from purport), what is the qualification for attaining the Supreme?
choices: Seeing all beings as non-different in their spiritual nature
questions.feedback: One must develop equal vision and recognize the spiritual equality of all beings.

questions.prompt: 23. In BG 13.30 (from purport), what is the completion of knowledge?
choices: Understanding both the individual and universal consciousness and their relationship
questions.feedback: Complete knowledge involves understanding both the soul and the Supreme and their eternal relationship.

questions.prompt: 24. In BG 13.6 (from purport), what qualities help one realize this knowledge?
questions.feedback: Spiritual virtues like humility and purity are essential for realizing this knowledge.

questions.prompt: 25. In BG 13 (summary), what is the core message?
choices: Understanding the field and its knower leads to liberation and eternal communion with the Supreme
questions.feedback: Chapter 13 teaches that knowledge of the body-soul distinction and the Supreme leads to liberation.
